title: When will the EU add the U.S. to its list of countries for which member states should gradually lift travel restrictions?
preds: With the recent restrictions imposed by both France and Germany there seems to be very low likelihood of any restrictions being lifted anytime soon. More than this with cases on the rise in the US it would be unlikely for other countries to decide allowing US residents in is a safe option.
The US does not have it's act together in terms of contact tracing and testing.  No country who values prudence would open up to the US.

News breaking that UK/US might agree on a reopening plan by the holidays. Don't think that would be enough have this question resolve, but merely acknowledging there is growing potential on a path to reopening.

All quiet on the Western front. I thought this would be an intricately interesting question but it turns out that there is almost nothing available publicly... other than the data, which has proved to be a poor indicator when taken in isolation!
They got a month.  High U.S. infection levels don't help.

Situation is worsening in the US and the EU by the day. We may very well see travel restrictions raised instead of lowered in the coming months if key countries continue to show upticks in their infection rates. Even if that does not occur, the federal response by the US is to act as if the pandemic is over, open everything up, and discourage mask wearing and other protective measures that could slow the spread. As we head into colder weather, there is little evidence our situation will be better by November 1st.

The situation seems to be the same as my previous forecast, but recent anecdotes published in Washington post are causing me to lower the chance it is between 10/1 and 10/31 2020. https://www.washingtonpost.com/travel/tips/americans-europe-covid-travel/
Reiteration. No new information to make me adjust - only factor is the time decay.

https://si.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/ https://www.statista.com/statistics/1101932/coronavirus-covid19-cases-and-deaths-number-us-americans/ The second wave is surfacing now and the US figures are not declining.
Pragmatically and politically an ease of restrictions is unlikely at the moment.

+21 to not before November 1st on passage of time and no signs of US hitting the threshold before then (similar daily new cases to EU in June). Leaving 10% on the possibility that with the EU's worsening conditions that they revise the requirement. https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&country=USA~EuropeanUnion&region=World&casesMetric=true&interval=daily&hideControls=true&smoothing=0&pickerMetric=location&pickerSort=asc

Council of EU secretary emailed me back. They are continuing to review countries but they have not changed the list since 7 Aug. Second wave occurring in most developed countries. US is starting to change its approach but (eg) its testing numbers are declining.
The Covid19 situation in the US is catastrophic and there is no indication that will change before 1 November.
Europe number going up. US at 40,000 Plus daily so no not soon.
I don't see any movement except the needle showing 34K new cases per day in the US.

i100% No as: 1. 35K new cases today 16th Septmber per WHO Dashboard https://covid19.who.int/region/amro/country/us
2. the USA has no consistent policy across the country for dealing with Covid-19
3. with daly deaths forcaste at 2k on the 1st Nov and also daily infections at 359K Nov 1st and a forcaste of an upward tend
US residents are likely to be non-gratta in the EU.

The question specifies that we are forecasting the date the US would be added and not the date it would take effect.  I was unsure if there would be a 2 week lag since the EU is reviewing this every 2 weeks, but it appears that it is only a 1 day lag based on past  additions. If the EU holds to its current criteria then countries will not be added until they are at the same tests/100000 level that the EU was at in mid June. The US is about double now what the EU was, but the EU is also now approximately double what it was in June.  I am thinking the EU will continue to keep the US out.  I will continue checking to see if new criteria is announced.

No fortnightly meeting since 7 Aug. Initially I thought they saw absolutely no reason to meet given the second waves but I'm starting to think they are formulating a plan for complete lifting. I cannot find anything to support or disprove this theory though.  Forecast shifts with time.

US infection rate is still ~2 times the EU average. US cases would need to accelerate their decline in order to fall below the EU average, while it seems more likely the decline will slow down. Political factors also make Americans less sympathetic in the eyes of Europeans. The list of approved countries remains very short.
"From October 1st, the ban on non-essential travel to countries outside the EU will be lifted and replaced with detailed travel advice for each country."

it is quite likely that the European countries will once again close their borders and suspend the Schengen space at some moment in the winter. Moreover, there are no signs of the pandemic being controlled in the US. Therefore, it is very unlikely that the EU would ease the travel restrictions to the US.

No update whatsoever from the European Council: I emailed two weeks ago and have received no reply; there are no meeting schedules publicly available to say when the next is; nor is there any explanation given as to why there has been no review meeting since Aug 7. They've gone silent. EU data is worsening in the southern countries (when is it ever not them?!). In response, does the EU loosen their criteria because they accept this will remain an ongoing issue or do they tighten criteria in an attempt to control it? The silence has me guessing - could they be drawing up new criteria? More unknowns than knowns at this point. I'm keeping my forecast largely the same as a few days ago.

+14 to not before November 1st. EU criteria appears to be a country must be doing the same or better than the EU was around mid-June. Neither the US or the EU appears to be close to that criteria. The reason for uncertainty is that because the EU is doing poorly right now it's feasible that if the US cases stay well below the EU this month they could reevaluate and consider travel from the US less risky. https://ourworldindata.org/covid-cases?country=~USA#what-is-the-daily-number-of-confirmed-cases Can't get the above link to work right but you can add EU to it and that's what I'm going by.
Upping probability of this not happening before Nov 1 given US covid levels and time remaining.
This country is Covid central. No one wants us.
They have not revised the list since Aug 7 and, as far as I can read, there has not been any explanations for that. I'll email the secretary and update you via reply to this.

If they were going to allow Americans in without meeting the criteria then it would make more sense to do so after the election (no point doing favours for a president who may not even be there in a few months). There is likely to be increased pressure from coronavirus in the winter, so probably not much willingness to relax restrictions on travel further.

New cases appear to be oscillating around the 40,000 case/day mark. We are no closer to meeting any of the EUs requirements than we were at the time of my previous post. Either the US has to get its act together as a nation, which is highly unlikely given the current climate of denialism and partisan ideological divides, or the EU has to lift restrictions or lower requirements, both of which are very improbable given the risks a second outbreak would pose to the region. Conclusion: we are still at least eight weeks from US citizens being allowed back into the EU.

I think the US meeting Criteria 1 is completely out of the question right now, unless the EU changes its policy thresholds. US testing per 100,000 has been decreasing steadily through August. Schools are back in all around America and, from the random sample of State Education Department websites, there is little being done to omit risks. The worst hit states are continuing to ignore Covid (e.g. Mississippi's Education website has no mention of Covid whatsoever). I imagine that, for Criteria 3, the EU will want to see the consequences of schooling on rates and any adjustments that are made which takes us to mid-Sept earliest. Election note: Neither candidate is willing to give up their crowds and rallies for Covid. Both are holding large gatherings, almost entirely without any masks worn and social distancing is very loose. I see no reason to change from my assessment two weeks ago.
EU is in a prestige competition with the US to some degree and will secretly relish bringing the US' image down a peg.

US rates falling steeper than I expected implying possible convergence with EU cause rates in October. This may reduce the marginal (covid) cost of opening up borders by enough to persuade them to add to list.  +2% for Sept
+7% for October
  httpss://www.google.com/amp/s/www.statista.com/chart/amp/22102/daily-covid-19-cases-in-the-us-and-the-eu/
Increased to 95% assessing that EU will wait until after the US elections.  Assuming they do not want to be a part of the election conversation.

What happened to them reviewing every two weeks?! 30 July
7 Aug
And no other review now until Sept 🤷‍♂️

Aug 29 the US has over 46K new cases for the day per WHO Dashboard and has no consistent policy across the country for dealing with Covid-19. Until there are nationally accepted and adopted policies and dramatically reduced incendences of new cases US residents are likely to be non-gratta in the EU.

While there have been a few tenuous signs that the infection rates in badly-hit parts of the US might be plateauing, it still seems unlikely that EU officials would risk lifting their restrictions for the next few months as the numbers are still dangerously high from a public health standpoint.  Officials might have concluded that the upcoming election could drastically change the way the pandemic recovery is handled, so the prudent thing would be to wait until after November 3.  Regarding the news on the air bridge potentially being completed before Christmas: even if it is completed for a city other than London (as the UK should be concluding its post-Brexit transition, however fraught that is, by EOY), officials would still have to contend with Americans traveling from high-risk areas of the US into Europe through low-risk cities like NYC, which makes the air bridge more difficult to construct and enforce.
Why? Numbers not going down after all, too much confusion over rules and national keaders not leading by example.

If the election/nomination speeches are anything to go by, they are demonstrating that the two candidates care more about showing a crowd than keeping the crowd healthy. It undermines any policies put in place.

It's not important at this point now that Criteria 3 is of interest but this page tracks whole EU stats: https://www.politico.eu/coronavirus-in-europe/. It was agitating me that I couldn't find them. Onto more relevant stuff... As @mattrjones1 noted, I've seen a report on discussions about air bridging London-New York. I don't think that kind of localised idea will have a bearing on whole country policy so I am not letting it affect my forecast for now. I'm trying to see which indicators are useful so I've shortlisted countries that seem to have potential to be added to the EU list. They are very few and far between but Pakistan seems the likeliest right now. Using the 'on the list' countries' policies should allow us to deduce what the EU are after from the US. I agree with @fisherdbus in that a sticking point might be the state-by-state approach. Obviously some states are just ignoring the whole thing - we're not going to see a New Orleans or a New York make outdoor masks compulsory as Paris has done 🤷‍♂️
Reports in The Times today that UK and other European countries in discussion about an air bridge arrangement in time for Christmas.
Politics, not science. Average figures show US cases density is now exceeding Eu’s by some 20%, it might revert to normal figures relatively quickly if things were taken seriously from top
Updating.  Still projecting they wait until after the US election.
US numbers coming down. Planning is still state to state. Will EU buy that?
I do not believe COVID-19 will be controlled in the US before 1 November 2020.  Therefore, the EU will not lift the restrictions.

Perhaps this is why data responsibility is being given back to CDC? 44,000 new cases WHO says for August 24th. That probably does not cut it. No coordination of testing or PPE. No funding passed. Aug 27th next decision date I believe. Not quite ready to give bin 4 more because cases across US are mostly dropping. Testing has maintained though thete is some concern about accuracy and time for results from some tests.

Criteria 1 update: The US's 14 day total new cases per 100,000 is 199. Way above the EU's guidance threshold of 16 per 100,000. Criteria 2 update: US's new cases are now showing a month of consistent decline, using a 14 day average which exceeds the EU criteria of having two weeks of decline. As I've posted previously, Criteria 3 looks to have the heaviest weighting in decision making. That's my conclusion after looking at the data for countries on the list and those who have been removed from the list - there are discrepancies in decision making unless we account for Criteria 3. Criteria 3 update:
I imagine the EU is particularly interested in the plans for schools given that it is the end of summer holidays almost everywhere in the northern hemisphere. US Schools are being given instruction from the Dept for Education: the recommendations make all the right noises under all the right headings.
[https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/schools-childcare/schools.html] However, I had a quick nosey at Florida's Dept for Education to see which recommendations they are forwarding to their schools... and there is absolutely no mention of coronavirus on the front page - you have to click 'Other Featured topics' [http://www.fldoe.org/]. "What?!" I hear you screech. Me too. So I did some digging on the Dept for Education Governor who sounds like he is pushing ethical boundaries [https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2020/aug/12/florida-rebekah-jones-ron-desantis-coronavirus] Mississippi - currently the worst for cases per 100,000 - does not mention coronavirus anywhere I could find on their Dept for Education website! Not even on the Community>Health and Wellbeing page! I'll stop now but you get the point! I've revised my forecast quite heavily on this **DOES ANYONE HAVE THE MEETING DATES FOR THE EU COUNCIL? THEY SAID EVERY TWO WEEKS BUT IT LOOKS LIKE THEY'RE DOING IT WHEN THE FEEL LIKE IT**
R rate is too variable , likely to be a second wave / perceived second wave with autumn, winter weather. Europe continues to see rises when travel restrictions are lifted
If US got down to 10000 a day maybe. 31,000 now.
Can see this somewhat as a political play against Trump
Will see second wave develop once schools reopen. This should cause a spike in numbers Oct-Nov with a fall not occurring until Dec.

I asked whether conditional listing would count; GJOpen has responded that it would not count. We will see the effects of any lobbying by Pompeo in Slovenia in the coming meetings. If the conversation does not include the US through September then I'd say the EU would be extremely unlikely to give Trump the political ammo during October (as noted in my last post, the EU makes very very few policy changes re US in the month before an election).

From mid-July to mid-August US daily case rates fell from 67k to 53k (from 20.5 to 16.5 per 100k pop in 1 month). Extrapolating the trend line with a longer tail as seen in other peaks would suggest perhaps 14in Sept, 12 in Oct, 11 on 1st Nov. I'd see this an optimistic reduction and would require tougher restrictions than trump has suggested he's willing to sanction.  EU incidence is on the rise and currently at 10k working out at 2.5 per 100k population. Following trend and presuming the trend gathers pace (as seen before) this would look like 4 in sept, 7 in Oct, 10 on 1st November. I think the EU have a better track record of slowing the spread so would not expect the trend to reach these heights.  Both of these suggest that the US will still have a higher case rate per 100k by 1st November implying which will not match the EU criteria. At face value this implies 100% not before 1st November.  The main thing which could reduce this is if the EU relax their criteria for economic reasons. I think this is plausible, but would still require a big drop in new cases in the US. The EU may face internal pressure when transatlantic business remains difficult after the summer holidays. Moves the dial 10% to October, 5% to September.  If a vaccine is approved and administered in the US this would drastically increase the chances, however this is almost impossible in September and highly unlikely by October, 2% to October.

The criteria requires that confirmed Covid cases in countries on the list are similar or below that of the EU's per 100,000 citizens over the previous 14 days (starting from June 15).
Countries must also have a "stable or decreasing trend of new cases over this period in comparison to the previous 14 days," while the EU will consider what measures countries are taking, such as contact tracing, and how reliable each nation's data is.

US still has many more new cases per day than the EU does. The EU criteria seems to be that a country must be doing similarly or better than the EU. Can't find cases per population for EU very easily but EU has a higher population so US cases per day would have to be lower. I think the US will have a long tail on this. October still seems like a possibility but probably less likely. https://www.statista.com/chart/22102/daily-covid-19-cases-in-the-us-and-the-eu/

Pompeo visiting Eastern and Central Europe. Most of the commentary is based on anti-China rhetoric, which is perhaps obvious given that these countries are China's route into Europe. Plenty of interesting details in the article below.
Ref: https://www.politico.eu/article/mike-pompeo-bohemian-rhapsody-us-foreign-policy/ NOTABLY, Slovenia is one of the countries presiding over the European Council at the minute, alongside Germany and Portugal. Those three countries get to set the agenda It is also the country of birth of Melania Trump. Pompeo managed to negotiate a 5G agreement with the Slovene president so there is clearly a willingness to cooperate. Might Pompeo's visit also be a subtle chance to lobby about travel restrictions?
Ref: https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/council-eu/presidency-council-eu/ Trade relations with the US are not scheduled until 9 November, the timing of which makes sense for longer term planning. Nothing scheduled through October regarding the US.
Ref: https://www.consilium.europa.eu/media/44868/st09250-en20.pdf Germany's presidency paper outlines their view of the EU and its role. Section I refers directly to the EU's Covid response and might reveals clues as to what they expect of the US before being accepted.
Ref: https://www.eu2020.de/blob/2360248/e0312c50f910931819ab67f630d15b2f/06-30-pdf-programm-en-data.pdf

In the US not much is changing. The US is still in the 52K new cases per day, while EU is 12K cases per day.
The US may have plateaued, but at an extrememly high rate, while the EU is still climbing. Neither situation is likely to change in the next two months as schools open and business tries to reestablish itself.

Base Rate: Not exactly a base rate for this, 11 countries reopening travel to EU as of 08 AUG Assumptions: The US will be one of the last countries to reopen
Cases in the US will not decline for months
EU cases continue to rise = continued restrictions
https://www.theatlantic.com/ideas/archive/2020/08/american-passports-are-useless-now/615244/
https://www.wsj.com/articles/rising-coronavirus-infections-restrict-european-holidaymakers-11597326586 15 Minutes of Reading:
Done Alternative Considerations:
UK/Ukraine/Croatia and many others are partially open to travel from US
US cases could decline sharply (highly unlikely)

There are currently three requirements to have restrictions listed. First, cases must be stable or decreasing in the last 14 days when compared to the 14 days prior. The US is currently trending downward, though its reporting is hardly stable. Second, countries must have cases per 100,000 close to or lower than the EU average. Right now, the US is at 1,595 while the EU is closer to 20-30. Third, non-tangibles such as testing, tracing, and treatment are taken into account. The US has not yet developed a universal testing and/or tracing plan, and treatments are no more developed than they were several months ago. As such, the US does not qualify for any of the requirements listed, and while they are beginning to decrease national cases, it will be months before they reduce cases enough to hit the second mark and will likely take at least as long to develop the needed non-tangibles to qualify. The only way it happens sooner is if requirements are waived altogether for the US, which is not impossible to remains highly unlikely.

(Based on limited data that I can find over the past ) The EU does not make big decisions regarding the US in the month - October - before US elections. Equally, any change is likely to be adopted by Trump as some sort of win/support for his campaign so the EU might want to make a change earlier rather than later as a hedge. On this logic, I am shifting my forecast towards September and away from October.  The US is defrosting relations by removing an outright ban on their citizens travelling abroad, although it is a tokenistic move to 'reconsider travel'. EU citizens remained banned from the US. Secondly, there is a complex poltical-economic situation: Current US-EU talks coincide with tariff discussions over Airbus (25%) and other EU goods (15%). Does the EU continue to demand coronavirus policy reform OR do they use travel easing as a pawn in tariff negotiations?
EU reviewed August 7. No change. Next August 21. I bet cases have to be below 10,000 a day. WHO situation report for today said US has about 54,000 more cases. It is a roller coaster.

https://www.thelocal.de/20200603/when-will-americans-be-able-to-travel-to-germany-again [[Paywall!]] https://www.afar.com/magazine/when-will-we-be-able-to-travel-to-europe - Greece considering US, UK allows US if they self-quarantine,  https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-eu-reaction/us-did-not-coordinate-notify-eu-about-travel-restriction-diplomat-idUSKBN20Z0F7 - I had not seen this previously. Trump 'went behind the EU's back' on banning travel in March, and pulled the 'you didn't ban China quick enough' card. So perhaps the EU-US travel is dependent upon some movement on attitudes towards China.
Probably not until we get the vaccine..
Cases per 100k people way off the average in the EU. But there is a decreasing trend in new cases, so some possibility of an earlier relaxation.

Very inlikely in the next two weeks. Cases still to high.
Low probability within the next month, but a future date makes slightly more likely.
I believe pressure might increase in the pre-election month to set a date.
As things stand, most likely not before November.

Given current rates in the U.S. the E.U. will be unlikely to lift restrictions in the short term. The current attitude towards preventative measures in the U.S. hinder a swift recovery. With 'second wave' predictions of the virus' spread, restrictions are likely to continue during that period.

This has largely been political.  Lots of people want to get rid of Trump.  Best way to do that is by overblowing a crisis.  No need to stop destroying our livelihoods until somewhere after the general election.
Perhaps economic pressure forces the hand of the EU, but the US population is not showing signs of adhering to public health guidance In the near term.  Fall weather into winter will only exacerbate

they hate trump and want to continue the story that he personally is to blame for 150k deaths 
therefore until the election the american people have to be reminded of the orange mans failure
Too high. Europe needs the tourist dollars. Us down (:-() to 22,000 new cases a day.

With September 23 days away, Europe doesn't seem likely to lift restrictions to travel from the US into EU. US covid situation is not great either. So, no reason for EU to lax its restrictions. I am moving my probabilities to the October and post-November brackets.

Criteria 1 is likely to be met in September.
Criteria 2 is met already and showing signs of confirming its downward trend.
Criteria 3 - EU unlikely to have a positive view of the testing policies varying county to county but US is testing more per 100,000 than almost all countries and their 8% positive is dead centre of WHO 'effective testing' thresholds (3-12%); EU might want to see strategy for, and effect of, schools opening as there is no strong data on which to model, but results will show mid-Sept; EU economies will have felt the 'bounce back boost' by end of August which may put pressure on opening up further; to what extent will neutrality in US election sway decision making?
I think they like to feel like they're better than the US. We still have decently high rates and the whole "dirty Americans" prejudice is going to keep Europe closed to America for a while.

US numbers not coming down fast enough though Europe would like US tourist dollars. With the ‘opening’ of schools posing a danger of spread and events like Biker week in Sturgis, S.D. not surge the overall lookout will change. 7 day average right now is 51,000. https://coronavirus.1point3acres.com/

US rate currently at 16 daily rate and needs to get to around 11 for the restriction to be lifted. It is currently on a steep downward trend projecting to reach the threshold in september, however the lifting of domestic restrictions will impede this as seen in the decrease of overall EU rate.

The US daily rate is about 55 000 per day. To reach 11 per 100K, the US rate would need to be nearer to 38 000 per day using a population of 330M. On current trends this could occur in 30 days at the earliest. However, school openings and large summer gatherings are likely to frustrate this decline considerably. Graphically its shown here
https://ig.ft.com/coronavirus-chart/?areas=usa&areasRegional=usny&areasRegional=usnj&areasRegional=ustx&cumulative=0&logScale=1&perMillion=0&values=cases

US average daily cases over the last 14 days is down to 17.8 per 100,000 (vs. EU criteria of being "close to" 11 per 100,000). Their testing has remained stable, so there is now a clear daily cases downtrend since 26-Jul. Criteria 1 and Criteria 2 look are trending to be achieved by late August. US schools open at the start of September. Scottish schools are opening mid-August so we should see what effect that has on rates before we see them in the US. I'll be looking into what measures schools are taking in US vs. other countries. The salient point now is the subjective - perhaps political - nature of Criteria 3.

Covid will not be under control in the US before Nov 1.
Politically,  Europe would not want to do Trump a favor by sharing good news, so no rush to open up to the US.
However, there may be  some push by airlines, and there may be  a safe  flying protocol, for example, relying on testing. If Europe does reopen, there will be a stronger push later in the year, when domestic tourism goes  down. August  and September are unlikely, as these are vacation months.
No sign US will have CoV2 under control before Nov1.  No desire in the EU to benefit current administration prior to presidential election.

Trying to figure out how to account for Europe starting to see surges amongst some of their own countries (such as Spain) and how that affects this question. I didn't account for that originally and that's a big miss on my part. Partially updating but need another day to think on it.

If the US had a forced shutdown for everyone for 4 weeks that started in mid-August we might contain the spread enough by October to lift travel restrictions. I think that's unlikely. A 2-week shutdown followed by a mandatory mask provision might get the transmission rate low enough to lift restrictions in 3-4 months. That puts us beyond November.

Given current trends of the spread of the virus, it is unlikely  the majority of EU countries will be willing to open to the US before November 1.  However this will be highly dependent on the developer of a successful vaccine.

The US will take two additional month to overcome the current COVID wave (in Florida, etc.). Then from November seasonal flu will kick in bringing also a second wave of covid and cases will go up again in Eastern States. There may be a window at the end of October/November in which the situation may look like good enough for the EU but most probably the end of the first wave and the beginning of the second will be basically back to back and discussion about lifting travel restrictions will happen in early 2021

The guidelines are revised every fortnight. Too much pressure from the airlines to reopen the transatlantic route. Also EU may move to test based system for entry [1]
Looks like everyone wants to reopen and looking for reasons to do so.
[1] https://simpleflying.com/why-covid-19-testing-is-the-key-to-reopening-eu-us-travel/
Congress' (Democrat led) rhetoric is strengthening against the Republican's attitude towards funding track and trace, which will feed into the perception for Criteria 3 (see Nancy Pelosi 8/6/20).

Belgium and France seeing upticks. In a situation where EU countries adding each other to quarantine lists, there is less chance of them wanting to complicate matters by adding third party countries. I note that Trump has allowed visas for students now which is a relatively warming move for him.
Considering the readiness of the vaccine.
We are going to be in quarantine for a while because people are freaking morons. And the president is the dumbest of them all.

[[First axiom: 25% starting point for each answer based on meeting numbers. Second axiom: 0% predictions are illogical.]] Criteria 1: 
- I had to weight-average the EU countries' numbers (I may have done this imperfectly but it is closer than any premade dataset I can find) to define the EU 15-Jun number = 0.84 14-day average daily cases / 100,000.
- US numbers at the data of the last EU meeting, 28-Jul, was 20.1. I note that Canada and Australia remain on the 'travel list' despite averages 1.2 and 1.4 respectively so there is obviously some leniency in their application of "close to or below".  Regardless, the US is far away.
- It will be interesting to see how flexible the EU will be with this criteria given that many of the countries on the list have shown increases between the last two meetings: If trends such as Japan +120% and Uruguay +350% continue, we are likely to see a shrinking list rather than a growing list! Criteria 2:
- At the meeting on 14-Jul, US average was 16.7; at the next meeting on 28-Jul it was 20.1.
- However, the trend is now turning downwards slightly. If this continues, the US should meet this criteria by the next meeting, 11-Aug. Criteria 3:
- Daily testing is stable around 230 per 100,000. That is a better rate than most countries in the world - it seems only tax haven countries are doing better. That remains the case when we look at testing vs. GDP per capita. 
- ~8% of tests in the US are positive vs. ~5% in the EU (note that this divergence is not an issue for Criteria 1). 
- US governance structure is devolved which presents to Europe as chaotic. (see 'ourworldindata.org' and 'europa.eu geographic distribution')
Current numbers in the US are too high for the EU to take chances. Having said that November will be the beginning of winter and the cycle may start again which means that March 2021 becomes likely
US failing to get COVID19-Pandemic under control; new challenges by flu season

Europe’s travel list is to be updated every 14 days, with new countries being added or dropped off depending on whether they are keeping the pandemic under control.
US does not have under control. With some schools and colleges opening probably not going to be sorted out till late fall.

The EU adding the US to a notional list would be considered a positive act that is mutually beneficial to both parties even though physical restrictions on travel will not be lifted until COVID-19 is under control in the US.  Pressure to be seen to act positively will increase prior to US elections but the EU is unlikely to even consider this move before COVID infection rates are in decline across the US. A convincing set of creative statistics to this end may be produced in October (5%) but more likely after November 1st (95%).

To get to levels where the US can safely partially reopen and to where the EU currently is, the US needs to start from the beginning and impose immediate lockdown. This will take at least 6 weeks to kick in.  So if everything is done perfectly, 2nd week of September is the very earliest the virus can be made under control. But with Trump politicising even the idea of testing, the US is very very far away from doing everything perfectly. It's true that states can take it upon themselves to do the right thing, but Trump's federal level failures will undermine the effort and Republican governers, petrified at taking on Democrats in the next election with the ire of Trump's hard core base, will help Trump sabotage America's response. So it is very unlikely the US will hand over the control of the virus to competent people and keep Trump's complaints rhetorical only. Will America be able to develop a highly effective testing and track and trace in time sufficient to reopen their economy? Very unlikely. Apparently simply knowing where the virus is is the "cause" of the virus numbers according to Trump. With such an attitude from the very top, the USs changes of getting over this before the next election are very slim.  So lets assign the probability of experts taking control despite Trump's protests as 2% per half month and rule out the first half of September. The chances the virus will still be raging by election is about 94%. And of course the boundary between being able to safely open up the economy and the EU letting citizens return is very close, particularly given case numbers are exponential in state performance and both events are tests for essentially the same underlying thing, namely whether the virus has reached safe levels.

It appears to me that the cases in the US are going to start dropping relatively rapidly. Looking at Youyang Yu's model, it looks like we shouldn't expect cases to start rising again in the US until November at the earliest. https://covid19-projections.com https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/press/press-releases/2020/07/30/travel-restrictions-council-reviews-the-list-of-countries-for-which-member-states-should-gradually-lift-travel-restrictions-at-the-external-border/ Looking at the criteria posted by the EU, one of the main 3 is a declining case count over the previous 14 day period. We should expect to meet that in August. The per capita number others have posted we are already close to achieving. Then the final restriction is nebulous. The fact though is that the EU is dependent on US tourism, and airlines / many businesses will be looking for the reopening of borders to the US in some fashion. Obvious wildcards include US/EU relations, the potential for cases to begin rising, as well as the nebulous 3rd requirement never being met.
There needs to be a sustained drop in the frequency of cases and no regional outbreaks in the US. The EU will be cautious but they will be keen on lifting restrictions on US travellers.

EU criteria demands <16 new cases per 100,000. 3 Aug reports show US new cases were 14.5 per 100,000 but as recently as 30th July the new case rate was ~20 per 100,000. The recent 14 day trend is turning down with daily tests stabilising since the beginning of July. So that criteria is beginning to look achievable, especially given the vagueness of the EU's wording: "close to" their average counts. The question that remains on that latter point is to what extent do the EU actually want to open to the US as that will influence their application of "close to" when looking at US data.
- https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/full-list-covid-19-tests-per-day?yScale=log&time=2020-03-31..&country=FRA~GBR~USA
- https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/cases-updates/cases-in-us.html
- https://covid19.who.int/region/amro/country/us The second criteria - I have already alluded to - is that the 14 day average new cases must be stable or falling. The third criteria is easily the most the vague, meaningless, subjective one. The best measure would be to compare US policies & data against EU policies & data. It is actually difficult to find coronavirus data for the EU as an economic area (does anyone have a good link?). WIDER: Economies are starting to take priority over healthcare of the populations - we see that with tourist hotspots opening up. What we have to consider is that it is only certain states that are experiencing dramatic rises (TX, FL, CA, NY) and that the EU might want to open up to the other states as a gesture of goodwill. The latter point, at the moment with lack of EU data (exc. Russia!), drives my thinking that it will occur earlier than my initial impulse led me to believe.

New cases per day peaked in late July. The number has been steadily decreasing since then, thanks to a combination of what Nate Silver says are many half-assed measures plus a percentage of people who have already gotten it and have some immunity.  Public school re-openings are the wildcard here.
New cases continuing to remain high per https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/cases-updates/cases-in-us.html

With schools and sports re-starting in much of the U.S. in August/September including some districts pushing in-person learning and even contact sports with minimal restrictions, it is inevitable that cases will rise in the Fall. The EU won't remove restrictions until our cases are falling.

Even with a huge policy change and fast fall in cases the US will not be at an acceptable medical position before 1/9/2020. The small chance reflects the outside possibility that political pressure in the form of trade policy or other could force a change by the EU. Based on the point EU opened up to other states, the general rate at which cases/day decrease in countries controlling the virus and the current position of the US then with the correct policy measures the US could feasibly reach a tolerable caseload before the end of September although it is probably more likely to be in the first few weeks of October. Another also quite likely scenario is that the appropriate policy measures are taken slowly and inconsistently across states which delays things until later in October or into November. A final scenario is that the US, gripped by nonsensical and partisan political discourse is unable to control the virus in the medium to long term until a vaccine is available, based on the outcome of the first peak I give this a good chance and so give the numbers as above.

US is a mess, but there's a realistic chance everyone begins pulling together after the worst has happened. I believe as of today, hospitals are on the brink of being , or starting to become, overwhelmed and a number of states which have been minimally effected will start to see first hand impact of the rona.
Starting position: rising cases + 2+-4 week incubation period + notice period --> if these 3 take a month each, then we hit November easily
5% is to cover the remote possibility that all states will take appropriate action to curb the spread of SARS-CoV-2 within the next few weeks.

As of end of July, the daily cotamination rate in the US is very high. The probability of this rate being lower than the EU one in one month is less than 1% for me. The economical benefits of reopening travel between US and EU is not important enough in comaprison with the economical impact of the coronavirus. 
After August, the incentive to open the border for toursim will be lower. The salient point of the EU’s criteria to allow citizens of third countries to enter the bloc is that the country should have no more than 16 new Covid-19 infections per 100,000 in the previous 14 days.
The US is experiencing 1,365 cases per 100,000 as of 31 July 2020 and is still in the first wave of the pandemic.
The Spanish Flu pandemic that was between 1918 and 1920 and used as a comparative example experienced four waves.

While the conventional wisdom says that U.S. travelers will be forbidden entry to the EU until our infection rates drop, the absence of tourism is playing havoc on the French, Italian, Spanish and Irish economies. The cases per 100,000 in the EU average out to be around 19.2 people. In the US the cases are over 1344 per 100,000 people. For travel bans to get lifted, rates need to drop to around the average for the EU, a decrease of around 98.5%. That is unlikely to happen, even without a second wave in the coming months. They may stretch these conditions for the US, but right now it would be impossible to justify allowing US citizens in.

The EU would like to re-start travel with the US, but will not be able to do so until US cases are lower than they were in May. This would imply total cases of, maybe, a few thousand per day. Maybe the US can get there by the end of September, possibly by the end of October, but probably not.

Regarding the epidemiological situation, third countries listed should meet the following criteria, in particular: number of new COVID-19 cases over the last 14 days and per 100 000 inhabitants close to or below the EU average (as it stood on 15 June 2020)
stable or decreasing trend of new cases over this period in comparison to the previous 14 days
overall response to COVID-19 taking into account available information, including on aspects such as testing, surveillance, contact tracing, containment, treatment and reporting, as well as the reliability of the information and, if needed, the total average score for International Health Regulations (IHR). Information provided by EU delegations on these aspects should also be taken into account.
Reciprocity should also be taken into account regularly and on a case-by-case basis
